repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Public Sector Management Program
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Sector Management
            Program Support Project for Zambia were as follows: outcome
            was moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was significant, Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some of
            the lessons learned include: Good analytical work is an
            important underpinning for program design, but it is not
            sufficient. Program design must be strategic, practical,
            prioritized, and take into account the implementation and
            absorptive capacity of the borrower.Project design based on
            a complex institutional reform agenda and its implementation
            would benefit from explicitly recognizing the iterative
            nature of the reform process. There should be provisions for
            frequent, in-depth supervision to inform periodically on
            critical intervention areas that may need to be adjusted and
            prioritized. Financing retrenchment of government employees
            can be deeply unpopular andcarries a significant
            reputational risk for the Bank. Unless retrenchment
            reformsare accompanied with complementary reforms and
            progress is closely monitoredto avoid reentry of civil
            servants the intervention is unlikely to be effective. The
            Bank has a rich history in retrenchment reforms and design
            of interventionsshould carefully draw on previous
            experience. Merit based recruitment of senior civil servants
            is a critical aspect to performancemanagement. Performance
            contracts are of limited value if senior civil servantsare
            politically appointed and can be dismissed arbitrarily as
            was the case in Zambia.Consolidating fragmented bank
            accounts takes significant political will and maybe given
            low priority during a time of economic growth and fiscal
            expansion. Idle balances should be of particular concern to
            countries prone to external shocks,  as the lack of a
            treasury single account means that these funds cannot be
            drawn on tocushion against unanticipated financing gaps. A
            contractual and implementation arrangement for IFMIS that
            assumes that acomprehensive off-the-shelf enterprise
            resource planning package wouldcorrespond to actual
            government and user requirements is not realistic.
            Significant configuration and parametrization will still be
            necessary. The Zambia case shows that the simultaneous
            implementation of all Integrated Financial Management
            Information System (IFMIS)modules is difficult and rarely
            feasible. Instead a sequenced roll-out approach,prioritizing
            core treasury reforms, can reap important low-hanging fruit
            and ensure that client capacity is not overburdened. The
            Bank may consider an approach where it supports training and
            technicalsupport, leaving the financing of system
            implementation to the client. When an implementation
            strategy involves an interim basic custom system, it is
            important that it is based on ex ante control of
            transactions. In Zambia the Financial management system
            (FMS) cannot be used to implement commitment or even basic
            budget or cash control.The introduction of advanced
            budgeting techniques, such as program / activity based
            budgeting, should be introduced only after a fully
            functioning IFMIS is in place.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Public Service Management Program
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Service
            Management Program Support Project for Zambia were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory and borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the Bank must
            tread carefully when getting into government-led,
            multi-donor pooled funding arrangements. Government
            ownership needs to be carefully assessed in terms of
            potential for political change and risk mitigation measures
            put in place to offset its effects. Projects involving
            far-reaching institutional and behavioral change need to be
            more realistic in setting objectives, targets and
            timeframes. To ensure effective project management, there
            must be a rigorous recruitment process for key positions.
            TTLs need better support when managing such complex projects
            and should be made more aware of the resources and support
            available to them within the Bank. The achievements under
            the Service Delivery Improvement Facility (SDIF) program
            raise a fundamental question about the relative merits of
            different approaches to institutional reform/change.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Public Sector Management Program
            Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Public Sector
            Management Program Support Project is to make public service
            delivery institutions and processes more effective and
            efficient by enhancing the efficiency and accountability of
            the management of public expenditures and the public service
            in line with the Republic of Zambia (GRZ) strategies to
            support poverty reduction and promote economic growth. The
            extension is necessary to allow the recipient to complete
            the implementation of activities that will ensure the
            achievement of the project objectives. The government has
            reaffirmed its commitment to these objectives and its
            willingness to continue the implementation of activities
            under the project. The recipient has shown new appetite for
            reform by ensuring that these reforms are part of the high
            level policy dialogue on budget support and are monitored
            through the newly introduced monetary and evaluation
            (M&E) department which reports on progress to cabinet,
            this is different from before where implementation was left
            to the technocrats with ineffective accountability
            mechanisms. The performance of the borrower is now
            satisfactory with senior management now focusing on
            providing oversight to and demanding accountability from the
            implementing component managers. The recipient has submitted
            the work plan, procurement plan and performance assessment
            criteria that covers the entire period of project extension
            to International Development Association (IDA). With this
            extension, the total life of this project will be 6 years 6
            months. This will be the first extension of the project
            closing date. The recipient proposed a 24 month extension in
            its letter of request for extension of closing date; however
            the project task team is of the view that an extension for a
            period of 18 months will be sufficient to complete the
            implementation of the remaining project activities. In
            addition, this shorter timeframe will help to impose time
            and budget constraints on the implementing agencies, thereby
            forcing them to implement activities in a focused manner and
            to remove any complacency that may arise from a longer
            extension period.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Second Public Service Management
            Program Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Public Service Management
            Program Support Project will help improve the process of
            determining budget allocations in order to further support
            poverty, as well as continuing to reinforce the role of the
            budget as an instrument to reflect government priorities,
            and discipline the use of public funds. Transparency and
            accountability will be further increased in the budget, and
            procurement systems, payments and incentive systems will be
            improved, and, ministry structures and management incentives
            will be realigned so as to increase performance and public
            service delivery. The project components are summarized as
            follows. Payment Reform component: given that full
            consolidation of allowances could not be achieved due to its
            effect on the government pension liabilities, the project
            will assist in the process of reforming the pension scheme,
            and revising the Pensions Act, and the approved Medium Term
            Pay Reform Strategy (MTPRS). Establishment and Payroll
            Control: implementation of the computer-based Payroll
            Management and Establishment Control (PMEC) system, to help,
            and ensure actual establishment is reflected in the payroll
            data. Financial and Policy Management: the Medium Term
            Expenditure Framework (MTEF) ensures the basis for
            disbursements, including that of the Activity Based
            Budgeting System, ensuring the requirement of Cabinet
            Memoranda that have financial implications to be cleared by
            the Ministry of Finance and National Planning (MoFNP), prior
            to Cabinet approval. Financial Management and
            Accountability: will ensure auditing through the Auditor
            General's report of government accounts, as per
            regulations of the 2002 government financial statements.
